commit_comments.body:
Ah, good point. The invalid argument is really `buffer`, which happens to have a sub-property with a bad value.

Logged https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/issues/44

Nice catch!

review_comments.body:
The problem here is not merely the parameter name - it's that the message to the developer won't make much sense. The message will now say something like "The 'buffer' parameter is out of range. Current value: -123". However, that is clearly not true. It's the `Offset` _property_ of the `buffer` parameter that is out of range.

This exception should probably not be an `ArgumentOutOfRangeException` at all. It should just be an `ArgumentException` saying that `The`Offset`property cannot be negative and cannot be greater than the size of the`Array`property's length.` and pass in `buffer` as the name of the argument.
That looks the same as what I said, no? BTW don't use string interpolation here because once these go into RESX files you can't use string interpolation - so stick to `string.Format`.
Remove this condition?

issue_comments.body: Is this still relevant @Tratcher @muratg @Eilon ? If so, we should move it to beta6

FYI, `RNGCryptoServiceProvider` is not yet available on CoreCLR, so we'll have to continue using `System.Random` there. Mono does have a `RNGCryptoServiceProvider` implementation that uses `/dev/random` or `/dev/urandom` on *nix. We'd need to sync up with CoreCLR on the plan for implementing this there.

Is this OK @Eilon @Tratcher @muratg @blowdart ?
Because I will likely introduce more bugginess and spend valuable time?
Don't forget CryptAcquireContext and figuring out which container/provider I'm supposed to use :)
@Eilon I think I'm going to need to get you to sign-off on doing that :)
I can do it though, it'll just take a bit for me to work out what to pull where and when. What are we going to do on CoreCLR Linux/Mac? Read from /dev/random ourselves?
WebSockets are not supported on CoreCLR Linux/Mac?

The framework RNG has a bunch of tendrils through the rest of System.Security.Crypto to support custom CSP Parameters and such. Would it be safe to assume we don't need to support that and can just use the default CSP (i.e. parameterless ctor for RNGCryptoServiceProvider)?
Apparently the travis builds are expected to fail because libuv isn't installed..?
@Tratcher well, @blowdart suggested this approach soooooo.... :)

At the moment it's very difficult for the WebSockets code to detect what kind of CoreCLR it is running on. @davidfowl and I talked and we think the most achievable result for beta6 is to #ifdef and use System.Random on CoreCLR. If that's not acceptable for now, we need to punt this bug to beta7 and work with the CoreCLR team to get either RNGCryptoServiceProvider or Platform-detection logic in ASAP. Regardless, we should definitely have a bug for improving the CoreCLR story for RNG here.
I rolled back a change I had to use native P/Invoke on CoreCLR for Windows because it is still extremely difficult to detect non-Windows CoreCLR. See #26 for further discussion.
Ok, ping @blowdart @Tratcher - Updated as per in-person conversations now.
Will merge when Appveyor passes (as mentioned above Travis is busted already)
Awesome, we just have to track down if we've got it in DNX now :)
Indeed :)
If only our Package Search tool had been updated _cough_ @glennc _cough_ :P
No, the handshake completes and then the connection terminates abruptly at some point. Some tests do succeed though.

Yeah, we're actively working to remove this and replace it with the implementation in corefx. I know performance will be a concern for them, but I don't know the specifics.

For reference, the implementation we're looking at is this: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/tree/master/src/System.Net.WebSockets.Client . It's nominally a "client" infrastructure but since send/receive semantics are the same on either send we're hoping to get something common that we can use out of that.

Until then, I don't think we're going to be investing heavily in this implementation; to avoid sinking work into something that's going away.

I tried to set up a standalone C# repro but the C# WebSocket libraries do not give access to sending ping frames, which is required to reproduce this issue, so I've done what I can to make the Autobahn Test Suite case easy to reproduce.

**Setup:**
1. Install CPython 2.7 - https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-2712/
1. Install Microsoft Visual C++ Compiler for Python 2.7 - http://aka.ms/vcpython27
2. Run `python -m ensurepip`
3. Run `pip install autobahntestsuite`
4. Run `wstest --help` to verify the test suite is installed

**Repro:**
1. Clone this repo, check out `anurse/100-repro`
2. Open WebSockets.sln in VS, and launch AutobahnTestApp in the IIS Express launch profile
3. Upon launching, the browser should pop and display the WebSocket URL for the server
4. Open PowerShell, cd to the `test\AutobahnTestApp` directory in this repo
5. Run `.\scripts\RunAutobahnTests.ps1 -ServerUrl [WEB SOCKET URL HERE] -Cases "5.7" -Iterations 20`

**Expected Behavior:** All iterations pass.

**Actual Behavior:** Some iterations will fail.

The test case is simply sending three frames:
- Opcode 1 (Text Frame) EndOfMessage=false "fragment1"
- Opcode 9 (Ping Frame) EndOfMessage=true "ping payload"
- Opcode 0 (Continuation Frame) EndOfMessage=true "fragment2"

The tests fail intermittently and without pattern. However, they do reliably fail within about 5-10 iterations. Something on the IIS end is dropping the connection because if you repeat the same tests directly against Kestrel it passes reliably (so far I've tried 100 iterations in sequence).

The issue **does reproduce in both IIS and IIS Express**
This will be fixed by moving to the CoreFX code. Confirmed that the test now reports strict-conformance in these cases with that code.
One note: I had to remove `UseZeroMask` from our client in order to support this. Since our client is basically going away anyway, this didn't seem like a terrible thing :)
:up: :date: - Fixed flaky large-buffer related test (turns out the test was just being a little too strict) and restored WebListener tests.
Synced some PR feedback from the parallel dotnet/corefx PR. Ready to merge upon green builds and sign-off from @Tratcher

I'll review it again but I was getting XML Doc comment warnings. I can probably create a PR to fix them as well, since they're mostly benign naming issues or missing docs. We build with `/xml`, not sure if corefx does, so that may be the cause.

I'd rather not mess with the corefx code in this case since if these warnings aren't occurring there, we'll keep having them pop up when we pull in new code. For now, since this code is temporary, suppressing these warnings is pretty benign.

I'm going to move the suppressions to the files themselves though (via our copy script)
Verified that this is an IIS issue. Created bug #8376897 in the WSSC TFS database and assigned to @pan-wang
:up: :date: - Added an Echo sample and removed the dummy project :)
The CoreFX code has been merged. Now merging this PR. Ping @Tratcher

I'm not a fan of bumping up timeout when we run into spurrious test, I think it hides real bugs. I think the question to ask ourselves is "would a user think this timeout is a reasonable timeframe for this scenario?". If the answer is no then the timeout is probably too high, and I'm going to guess that 10 minutes (and maybe 5) is too high.

issue_comments.body: :shipit:
The overwrite should be optional. Different implementations will have different features, bugs, perf, etc..
7.5.1 - Send a close frame with invalid UTF8 payload - Clean close with protocol error or invalid utf8 code or dropped TCP.

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-5.6

```
   Text

      The "Payload data" is text data encoded as UTF-8.  Note that a
      particular text frame might include a partial UTF-8 sequence;
      however, the whole message MUST contain valid UTF-8.  Invalid
      UTF-8 in reassembled messages is handled as described in
      Section 8.1.
```

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-8.1 - Handling Errors in UTF-8-Encoded Data
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-10.7 - Handling of Invalid Data
Updated. The utf-8 validation has been completed and now 100% of the autobahn tests pass.
Now passing with 100%.
@victorhurdugaci @muratg
ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read the data in Netmon. It just makes the masking step a no-op so it should work with any server.

ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read your data in Netmon. 0 is a legal mask per spec, just not recommended (see http://xkcd.com/221/). It makes the masking step a no-op, but servers shouldn't even notice.
Yes, moved to beta6.

The synchronization you see in CommonWebSocket is used to prevent Ping/Pongs from colliding with user Sends. See:
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L377
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L164
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L124
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.WebSockets.Protocol/CommonWebSocket.cs#L489

This also happens to protect a user from calling Send multiple times by mistake, but that does not mean concurrent sends are actually supported.  You can see by the way the locks work that the user gets no benefit from calling Send multiple times at the moment. If it becomes a problem then we can add additional checks to notify users when they call send multiple times by mistake.
We already use SemaphoreSlim.WaitAsync, so it's async blocking.

Interestingly the MSDN docs do not specify a required semantic: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.websockets.websocket.sendasync(v=vs.110).aspx

I understand the portability concern. Since the overlapped sends are not fully supported we should actively discourage developers at runtime from doing it (e.g. throw).

That said, if we decided to support overlapped sends in a specific implementation, we may do that even if other implementations didn't. Consistency is good, but sometimes we diverge on purpose to add value. Otherwise we'd never need more than one implementation.  We just need to be clear about the differences and why you'd use one over the other.
Seems ok to me, but good luck with @blowdart. @Eilon?
Which server are you running on?
What client are you using?  Maybe it's incompatible. Try this one for reference: https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/test/TestClient/Program.cs

IIS does not support the Upgrade feature, it supports WebSockets natively (e.g. you don't need to use the websocket middleware). WebListener supports both Upgrade and WebSockets natively, so using the middleware is optional.  Kestrel only supports Upgrade and requires the middleware for WebSockets.

Upgrade isn't a capability that can be added by middleware, it must be naivety supported by servers. Most servers do not give you the direct access to the underlying connection that you need for WebSockets.
That's not available yet. We used to have this kind of startup detection in Katana, but haven't developed a replacement.

Upgrade is supported by WebListener on Win8+, or by Kestrel on any OS.

Note that IIS and WebListener have native WebSocket support, so the middleware won't do anything on those by default.

Oh so it's behaving as expected, it's just noisy. A disconnect is an error in the WebSocket protocol, it's just not a very interesting one. We can check the flow and see if it can be simplified.

While we do have WebSockets working, we don't have the resources to do extended testing, performance, and stress work on it until after 1.0. That's why we're not including it. Use it at your own risk.

There is already a built in timer based ping-pong system.
https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server/WebSocketOptions.cs#L24

Ping and Pongs aren't uniquely paired in the protocol, they are just control messages used to keep the pipe alive and/or check for pipe failures. You don't need to verify a pong is received for every ping, the  ping alone should be enough to verify the pipe is active or trigger a send failure (e.g SocketException).
Does it work if you run Kestrel directly without IISExpress?
We'll have to investigate. @pan-wang, can you take a look?
:shipit: in dev.

There wasn't any support for a netstandard client until recently. See https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/d0dc5fc099946adc1035b34a8b1f6042eddb0c75/src/System.Net.WebSockets.Client/src/System/Net/WebSockets/ClientWebSocket.cs
FYI: That's a strait quote from the spec. That said, it shouldn't be in the API doc comments, move it into the method body.
A wireshark trace would be helpful.
No idea, that's a question for corefx.
Thanks. FYI: We're working on 1.0 and won't get back to this for a few weeks.
Yes, that should work for WebSocketClient. I assume you have something set up on the server side to validate them? JwtBearer?

The ping/pongs serve two purposes:
1. They encourage the connection to stay open with occasional traffic (with emphasis on the occasional; 1 second is very high, 30 seconds is more common).
2. Detecting if the connection has been broken. Any outgoing write on a broken connection will trigger a reset from the remote party, causing the pending read on that connection to fail.

So the answer to your real question is that you detect the client disconnect by always keeping a pending read on the WebSocket. Note that the current implementation requires this to process incoming pings anyways.
We decided not to ship Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Client to nuget.org for RC2. It was only ever a proof of concept and it relies on undocumented behaviors of .NET Framework's HttpWebRequest.

The server package has had a lot of usage and seems stable. It shares 90% of the code paths with the client package. Most of the other code paths are those already in use in System.Net's ClientWebSocket via HttpWebRequest. It's only the combination of the two that hasn't been as well tested. Feel free to build from source and submit PRs if needed.
Change `public async void Update()` to `public async Task Update()` and make sure the caller `await`s it.

@fhelwanger it's too soon to say. It depends on the features you'll need. The new client is starting out pretty basic, where this one builds on all of the features of HttpWebRequest.  Building this client from source is your best option for now.

commits.message:
Fix NuGet project description ASP.NET 5 > Core (#120)

changed leftover "ASP.NET 5" in project.json description to "ASP.NET Core"

Increase .travis.yml consistency between repos
- aspnet/Universe#349
- minimize `dotnet` setup time; no need for caching
- `KOREBUILD_DNU_RESTORE_CORECLR` env variable isn't used anymore
- no need for libuv v1.4.2 w/ current Kestrel packages

One build to rule them all
- well, at least VS and command-line builds will share output
- part of aspnet/Coherence-Signed#277

React to HttpAbstractions change: `WebSocketAcceptContext` in new namespace
- see issue aspnet/HttpAbstractions#590 and pull aspnet/HttpAbstractions#589

Remove project name from output path
- aspnet/Coherence-Signed#187
- remove `<RootNamespace>` settings but maintain other unique aspects e.g. `<DnxInvisibleContent ... />`
- in a few cases, standardize on VS version `14.0` and not something more specific

Update `build.cmd` to match latest template
- aspnet/Universe#347
- `%KOREBUILD_VERSION%` doesn't work without this fix

Move Travis to supported Linux distribution
- use Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty)
  - Travis support for Trusty is in Beta and currently requires `sudo`
- run `dnu restore` with DNX Core since aspnet/External#49 is not fixed in Mono versions we can use

Explicitly choose Mono 4.0.5

  - e.g. when Travis updates default Mono version in `csharp` bundle

Change hardcoded `bash` shebang to `env`
- aspnet/Home#695
- support various `bash` installation locations
- in particular, enable building on FreeBSD
Update .xproj files for Microsoft.Web.AspNet.* -> Microsoft.DNX.* rename

IMO it's very important in xplat/pluggable libraries like WebSockets implementation to maintain exactly the same semantics (including error handling) among different implementations/platform. One could depend on implementation specifics for example task queuing on async semaphore instead of providing upper level buffering/queuing and for example application will work correctly when .NET Core self-hosted but will fail under Helios throwing InvalidOperationException.

Yeah exactly. Unclear semantics on such core APIs are one of the root causes of inefficient networking implementations or portability issues. That's exactly why I started from browsing source code of different implementations due to lack of official documentation on this problem.

In case you decide to add support for Overlapped Sends/Receives please consider adding: `bool SupportsOverlapped { get; }` or something like that with clear semantics. In such situation libraries utilizing WebSocket can check for this flag and make use of optimization you are implementing ;).

For example I am implementing an xplat RPC library over web sockets and want it to be as efficient as possible (especially in terms of latency) but also interopable (working among different kinds of hosts).
If you're already branching based on OS to use the Mono one, then why not pinvoke if you're on Windows whilst we wait.

A single if statement is more bugginess? I have way more faith in you than that Andrew :D

As gross as it is the RFC specifies PRNGs for a reason and we should make an effort here until CoreCLR catches up.

CryptGenRandom is what you want - https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa379942%28v=vs.85%29.aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396
Well yes, but just lift it from 4.6 framework code :p
In Mono use their class, in Linux/Mac ... ummm, abort with notSupported? :D
If you can't support the RFC's intent should you support it at all?
I think it'd do for now, until we can switch to their version.
Or not support on core? Has anyone talked to coreclr about their timescales?
<channeling @Eilon> :shipit:

Heh, I thought that `RNGCryptoServiceProvider` support had been recently added to CoreCLR?
https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/commit/f394692c7de8cb9e3e9c1b6d3a72ba1196e0d28b

Is there an API I can use to query the server features so I can figure out whether the web server supports websockets natively, or if it will after using the WebSocket middleware or it if won't at all?

I'm closing this issue as the root cause is websockets are not supported on Windows 7 with IIS/WebListener.
There is no way to detect in the ASP.NET application whether the OS+webserver+WebSockets middleware will support websockets or not. It would be nice if there was.

Whether or not multiple sends are supported has an effect on the user-code, so the behavior should be specified in the documentation and should not vary across implementations.

In my opinion, every implementation should support multiple SendAsyncs.

Whether SendAsync and ReceiveAsync can be used simultaneously needs to be clarified as well.

Some 'typical' websocket use-cases which benefit from concurrent operation support:
- sending the same data to a number of client WebSockets (you don't want to await the Send for each client)
- sending event notifications from multiple independent sources to a client WebSocket
- accepting commands on a WebSocket and providing the reply after async execution (multiple replies can occur simultaneously)
See https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/issues/61
@rposener what server are you using?

What should happen:
the value you give in AcceptWebSocketAsync should be set in the WebSocketAccept context [here](https://github.com/aspnet/HttpAbstractions/blob/3a97a6bdfdcc3787bf4b68cecdf277588de5ee76/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http/Internal/DefaultWebSocketManager.cs#L60).
Then read from the context [here](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server/WebSocketMiddleware.cs#L97), passed on to [GenerateResponseHeaders](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server/WebSocketMiddleware.cs#L117) to end up in the header IEnumerable [here](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Protocol/HandshakeHelpers.cs#L79), which then becomes part of the response headers [here](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server/WebSocketMiddleware.cs#L120).

Stepping through [AcceptAsync](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/blob/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server/WebSocketMiddleware.cs#L87) may give you an idea of what the issue is. If you check out [Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server](https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/tree/0f9e4eba024078d2b0b2f1efb70a594b9ee70d0c/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Server) and add it to your 'src' folder, you should be able to set a breakpoint in that method.

With the adoption of the ManagedWebSocket semantics are the same accross implementations: "supports exactly one send and one receive on each WebSocket object in parallel".
This means we can close this issue.

I think hard disconnects/dirty close rather than close messages; can recreate easily by connecting via websockets with a client then terminating it (the client)
It didn't do anything untoward - other than being very messy for the error log

Feels a bit like this sort of state: https://github.com/SignalR/SignalR/blob/3a219c101587333d562f04f30903d50ad9773e1c/src/Microsoft.AspNet.SignalR.Core/Owin/WebSockets/WebSocketHandler.cs#L237

Is a disconnect rather than an error

Yea, agreed, but its a bit like someone disconnecting mid http download - probably don't care too much; whereas a `fail` is like a "go investigate what's wrong" type thing. Could be a `debug`, `verbose` or even just "disconnected" `info` type report?

@cherrydev at a guess because WebSockets without the middleware is specifically tied to WebListener on a Windows Server version 2012 or above; and its another code path to maintain. Whereas the middleware works cross platform on all operating systems and all server versions? 

Also the non-middleware version causes memory fragmentation between pinned buffers; and performance degradation unless you jump though a few hoops.

WebSocketReceiveResult should be a struct https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/4530 :cry:

Not had any issues detecting disconnects and have tested thousands of disconnects a second; clean and through process and VM termination. However, we are generally constantly reading and writing on the sockets. I haven't explored much with mostly idle websockets.

Idle on a good connection should timeout within 2.5 mins; on a bad connection where transmission has reached 240secs it could take 20mins to timeout? (you should be using `HttpContext.RequestAborted` or a linked token source with it, for ReadAsync and WriteAsync)

I assume that this means that SignalR will not make use of WebSockets anymore unless the WebSockets middleware is explicitly added in?  Is there a discussion thread somewhere where I might get an idea of why it's been removed from the roadmap?

@cherrydev SignalR and WebSockets has been on the chopping block for quite some time. I do believe that SignalR using long polling will be an option, but I could be wrong on that.

Sweet. Thanks for the additional info -- I saw that roadmap some months ago and new SignalR wasn't going to happen for v1, but that's not that big of an issue -- there are plenty of ways to work around it for those that need it.

It works, but I had to specify `SslProtocols.Tls` as the protocol, otherwise (Default, Tls11 or Tls12) client and server throw an error about not having common algorithm:

```
var httpsOptions = new HttpsConnectionFilterOptions() {
                SslProtocols = SslProtocols.Tls,
                CheckCertificateRevocation = false,
                ClientCertificateMode = ClientCertificateMode.AllowCertificate,
                ServerCertificate = new System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2("....pfx", "...")
            };
```

It works without an error on IIS (Windows 10), fails only in Kestrel.

thanks for the quick follow-up. the use-case i am most concerned with is a half-open state, say, by losing a wireless connection or having an ethernet cable unplugged.

enforcing a read-timeout on the underlying TCP stream is one way to check for an unplugged cable.

it's not clear how sending a ping, by itself, is enough to verify the client is still connected (if the client is unreachable), unless you are willing to wait for the TCP protocol itself to timeout (which may be a long time).
Regular (desktop) .NET 4.6, although we were looking into either .NET Core or Mono in the future for cross-plat.

All non-abstract classes in `System.Net.WebSockets` namespace that come with desktop .NET are Win8+-only, aren't they?

We've been using websocket-sharp so far, and it works fine. But now we need a client library that supports Windows authentication (NTLM), and there seems to be a shortage of those - indeed, I don't think there even is any library that advertises such support explicitly, but it seems to work with `Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebSockets.Client` because it wraps `HttpWebRequest` (and exposes it for customization). I assume it also works with the desktop `ClientWebSocket` implementation that uses Win8 native websocket API under the hood, but Win8-only is too restrictive, so we didn't even consider it. The .NET Core implementation looks like it doesn't support auth at all right now.

How stable is the existing AspNetCore client implementation is in practice? I understand that it's not officially supported in any case, but on the scale of "completely untested prototype" to "plenty of people are using it and seem to be doing fine, but no promises"?

Worst case, the implementation looks small enough that we can fork and maintain it if need be, until a better solution comes along (or until most users move to Win10).

For the sake of clarity, the product that we'd like to use it in is this:
https://github.com/Microsoft/RTVS
cc: @davidsh, @cipop
What warnings for what code? corefx code should be building warning-free.
https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/pull/10792
Now that this is using the same implementation as from CoreFx, this is no longer an issue, right?

review_comments.body: This change in particular, I'll be interested in knowing whether it helps/hurts scalability in your scenarios.  I've been tempted to revert it, out of a concern that we could be taking all of the buffers from the pool for long-lived websockets.

commit_comments.body: This generates "Offset" instead of "buffer.Offset", since `nameof()` uses the name of the last component in a qualified name. There's no parameter named "Offset". (And I think the idea with `Argument...Exception`s is that they should just refer to the parameter and not to a property path.)

review_comments.body: Recommend parens around (b & 0x3F) for clarity.
System.Net.Websockets.Client should be System.Net.WebSockets.Client

`document.location.port` is empty if it is the default port:

``` js
var port = document.location.port ? (":" + document.location.port) : "";
```
